      <div class="blog-item-wrapper blog-side-by-side-item-wrapper" data-content-field="main-content" data-item-id="">
  <article id="article-" class="h-entry entry hentry post-type-">
  
    <div class="blog-item-inner-wrapper">
      <div class="blog-item-top-wrapper">
        <div class="blog-item-title">
          <h1 class="entry-title entry-title--large p-name" itemprop="headline" data-content-field="title">7.5 Reasons Why Twitter Will Replace Your College Diploma</h1>
        </div>
        <div class="blog-item-meta-wrapper">
          

          <div class="blog-item-author-date-wrapper" data-animation-role="date">
            <time class="dt-published blog-meta-item blog-meta-item--date" datetime="Jun 12" pubdate data-content-field="published-on">
              <span>Jun 12</span>
            </time>
            <div class="blog-meta-item blog-meta-item--author p-author author" data-content-field="author">Written By <a href="/?author=5d306139c4fbc8000161f907" class="blog-author-name">Brendan Cahill</a></div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>

      <div class="blog-item-content-wrapper">
        <div class="blog-item-content e-content"><div class="sqs-layout sqs-grid-12 columns-12" data-layout-label="Post Body" data-type="item" data-updated-on="1591976966460" id="item-5ee3a3c20c342a1acf777ad5"><div class="row sqs-row"><div class="col sqs-col-12 span-12"><div class="sqs-block html-block sqs-block-html" data-block-type="2" id="block-052221c38d14aa664852"><div class="sqs-block-content"><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><a href="https://medium.com/@cahillkicking?source=post_page-----b04e4ca0bf61----------------------">Brendan Cahill</a></p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><a href="https://medium.com/@cahillkicking/7-5-reasons-why-twitter-will-replace-your-college-diploma-b04e4ca0bf61?source=post_page-----b04e4ca0bf61----------------------">Jun 11</a> · 8 min read</p><blockquote><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Why a strong Twitter presence might do more for your professional success than a college diploma will.</p></blockquote><h1 style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>But first — why Twitter?</strong></h1><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">I  wouldn’t say I am a Titan of Twitter but I have used it to create a  decent following that I’ve leveraged into a 6-Figure business at one  point (you can read about that one’s unfortunate demise here) with less  than 3K followers and am leveraging it once more to build new ones.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">As  a private coach I’ve been able to develop connections with coaches at  top tier college football programs, current and former NFL Pro Bowl  players and coaches and generate countless leads in referrals to my  coaching business all through Twitter.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">In  2020 it isn’t uncommon during an informal job interview for the  interviewer to simply ask “Follow me on Twitter I’ll check your stuff  out.”</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Right  now your brand is being built. It can be done by default by the company  you’re working for or school you attend or you can do it by design,  rally your tribe and create more opportunities for yourself than you  ever could have dreamed a college diploma would give you alone.</p><h1 style="white-space:pre-wrap;">0.0 What is college for?</h1><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">The  average American education path looks like this: Get good grades to get  into a good high school. Get into a good high school to get good grades  to get into a good college. Get into a good college to get a good job.  Get a good job to have a good life.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">While  I am vocal critic of college, college was very good to me. I made  lifelong friends, had fun, was mentored by great professors and met my  future wife there. As a dating service and sleep away camp for young  adults, college is unmatched.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">But,  as good an experience that I had in college it is impossible to ignore  the combined impact that the internet, social media and brand building  have all had on tearing down the monopoly that higher education once had  on the American Dream.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong><em>Twitter might be the biggest disruption of them all.</em></strong></p><h1 style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>1. Twitter Treats You As A Brand</strong></h1><blockquote><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">In  the 20th century you went to school to train to work for a famous  brand. In the 21st century you are the brand that companies want to work  for.</p></blockquote><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">A brand is simply what someone expects from you, or your reputation.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Pre-Twitter  this reputation relied on bosses and supervisors to develop for you.  Now, Twitter allows you to cultivate a specific reputation with every  tweet, like, retweet or comment.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">In the 20th century people went to school to train to work for a famous brand.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">To  do this they tried their best to go to schools with famous brand names  like Harvard, or Yale or Stanford. The more famous a brand of school you  went to the more famous a brand company you can work for. If you want  to work for Apple, you could better do it as a Standford graduate than  Glendale Community College graduate.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Now, you get to decide what your reputation is. And that’s scary for a lot of companies.</p><h1 style="white-space:pre-wrap;">2. Twitter Is A Portal To The Soul</h1><blockquote><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">We can’t read minds — yet. But, Twitter is very close.</p></blockquote><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">In  a few taps you can see every post, every comment, every like and every  piece of content a person has ever created. You can peer into the depths  of their mind and soul to see what makes people tick.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Even  cooler, you can decide to drop into that thought thread and add your  own valuable insight into someone’s running conversation with other  like-minded people.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">And,  if those people resonated with anything you said, they too might drop  into your own thought threads, comments and DMs to begin building a  relationship with too.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">If you’re looking to understand the hopes, dreams and fears of your ideal market, Twitter is a great starting point.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><em>(As an aside — if you can find this much information out publicly on Twitter just imagine what they’ve got on you privately!)</em></p><h1 style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>3. Twitter Made The World Flat (Again)</strong></h1><blockquote><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Columbus might have proved the Earth was round in 1492 but Jack Dorsey made it flat again in 2006.</p></blockquote><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Twitter has removed all gatekeepers between you and people you want to interact with.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>The Silicon Valley term for this is “disintermediation” — or removing intermediaries between people and brands.</strong></p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Entire  industries are based off positioning themselves at information choke  points and then charging for access to that information.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Higher  education positioned itself at the choke point of “how do I make sure I  get a good job?” and charged handsomely for access to that information.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Now,  there are 15 year old YouTube stars making 7 figures through their  iPhone. It’ll be tough to convince them of the value proposition of  attending a $70K/year liberal arts college when the average graduate  ends up working at Starbucks for minimum wage the first few years out of  college.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">In  theory, there is now no real barrier between you and Trump. If you  tweet something outlandish enough his way, he could tweet you back and  drive the next 24hr global news cycle. This is both very cool and scary.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Secretaries,  mid-level management and other gatekeepers now have less power than  ever over who can reach their bosses. If you have a compelling enough  offer and someone sees enough value in it you can get through to anyone.</p><h1 style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>4. Twitter Is A Hyper Network</strong></h1><blockquote><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">You’re just one retweet away from going viral.</p></blockquote><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Metcalfe’s law states that a network’s value compounds with every additional node added to it.</strong></p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">When  the telegraph first came out, it was not very valuable if only one  person had it. But, the more people who adopted the telegraph the more  valuable it became.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">And, so it is with Twitter.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">If  only 10 people used Twitter it would not be very valuable. But since  there are 321 million active users on it (as of February 2019) and is a  $3.5 billion dollar company it’s value is undeniable.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Overnight  you may be retweeted by someone with 100K followers which then gives  you 2,000 new followers, and 80 DMs asking you about collaborating on  your new business.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Twitter isn’t bound by physics. It is a force multiplier that lets you connect with anyone, anywhere and at anytime.</p><h1 style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>5. Twitter Is A Low Cost Litmus Test</strong></h1><blockquote><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">You can test without going broke (or crazy).</p></blockquote><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">One analogy I enjoyed from David Perell, <a href="https://www.perell.com/" target="_blank">whose got a great course on Twitter you can find here</a>, is that Twitter like 24/7 Zoom Call you can tune into at anytime.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Empowered  by distance and not knowing you personally Twitter will viciously slay  any idea it doesn’t like. This will save you a lot of potential time and  frustration in market research.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">You  can accomplish in one tweet market research that might have cost the  Mad Men of Madison Avenue $100K+ of work to do over the course of  several months.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Personally, I like posting a generic tweet “<em>Hey  guys I’m looking for 8–10 people who are serious about learning a bit  more about how to xyz. DM/Comment if you’d like to test run my new  course”</em>.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Then,  I’ll make a private DM group (you can add up to 50 members on a single  Twitter DM right now) and begin the conversation there.</p><h1 style="white-space:pre-wrap;">6. Twitter Builds Your Tribe</h1><blockquote><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">While not yet clients or customers, building an audience is the first step to finding them.</p></blockquote><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Some  ESPN personalities have more followers than ESPN itself does. Some NY  Times reporters have more followers than the NY Times do.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Pre-Twitter,  if you lost your job that was it. You would have to start over at a new  company — low man on the totem pole. Now, even if you get fired from  your job, you will still have your online audience that you can leverage  to create revenue generating opportunities for yourself.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Better  yet, losing your job always makes for a great read. You can turn it  into your flagship blog post that will build your credibility and  authority in your audience’s eyes as someone who know how to recover  from job loss, start their own business and so on.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Twitter is the perfect first stop on building your audience and eventual sales funnel.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><strong>Twitter lets you take your following with you.</strong></p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Across  America the unemployment rate is through the roof. What if when you  were let go because of COVID19 you simply shrugged, flipped open your  Twitter account with 10K+ active audience members and tweeted out you  were starting a new business or launching a new course and it made you  $5K?</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">The  days of businesses having a monopoly on your brand are over. In fact,  businesses are scared to death of the power that their employees’  personal brand can now wield upon their companies. In the age of each  person having their own unique brand, the faceless corporation will  lose.</p><h1 style="white-space:pre-wrap;">7. Twitter DM is the New Email</h1><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Right now there are multi-million dollar deals, scholarship offers, and business discussions occurring on Twitter DM.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">The  DM is today what email was 15 years ago — an uncluttered direct line of  communication between you and someone who can say “yes” to your dream.  Like the dark web, 98% of what goes on inside Twitter occurs here.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">In  theory, once someone follows you back they are open to you DM’ing them.  I would recommend if you do DM someone you take the following  guidelines:</p><ul data-rte-list="default"><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Seek  to give to that person first. Do you have something valuable that might  benefit a project they are working on? Could you connect that person to  someone else that they might find beneficial to know?</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Seek  to learn from that person first. Everyone enjoys answering questions  about things they are passionate about. Craft 2–3 succinct and  insightful questions regarding a post, project or podcast you heard that  person on to ask.</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Give  it time and space. Just because you were responded to once via DM  doesn’t mean you are best friends. I like a span of 2–4 days in between  DM’s when trying to build a relationship with a new person.</p></li><li><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">DM’s  are not a replacement for conversation but rather the first step to  having one. When possible, transition your DM conversation “offline” to  over the phone or email. With every cell phone number or email that  person grants you permission to you build a little bit more trust.</p></li></ul><h1 style="white-space:pre-wrap;">7.5 Twitter Won’t Make You Happy</h1><blockquote><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">It will just make you more or less of what you already are.</p></blockquote><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">10K  + followers never made anyone happy. And, money only solves money  problems. Even if you are making some it won’t change who you are as a  person.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">Twitter  and social media are great at building connections but not great at  building conversations. The magic of Twitter comes when you can leverage  a connection made on its platform into a real-life relationship,  mentorship or friendship.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;">In  the future everyone is going to be their own brand that companies will  apply to work for. Twitter is just one of numerous other platforms where  people will be able to intentionally craft that brand, make money from  it and ultimately live life on their terms.</p><p class="" style="white-space:pre-wrap;"><a href="https://twitter.com/cahillkicking" target="_blank">I  write about turning myself into a brand and monetizing it to achieve  financial independence. Follow me here on Twitter for more updates along  the way.</a></p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
